__data__.text: Claude Wilschefski, born in Maryborough, Queensland, Australia on December 2, 1902, was the youngest of three children to German-born Henry Wilschefski and English-born Mary Frances Carter. His siblings were Percy Lawrence Wilschefski and Annie Evelyn Wilschefski. Henry passed away in 1903, and Mary remarried Francis Martin List in 1907, a German immigrant who had five children with her, including Norman Andrew List, Alice Holly List, Francis Martin List, Edna Marjorie List, and Irene Maude List. Claude's half-siblings were born between 1908 and 1915, with the first, Norman, passing away as an infant.

In the years following 1915, Claude Wilschefski, his mother Mary, and her second husband Francis Martin List relocated to New Zealand, residing in Glen Eden by 1919. Francis, a seasoned rugby league player, occasionally played alongside Claude. Initially captivated by rugby league in Queensland around 1912, Claude continued his passion in New Zealand. After moving to Auckland, he made his debut with the Kingsland Rovers' third-grade team in 1921, as indicated in an Auckland Star team list on June 10. His older brother Percy might have been the other List mentioned in the team. Claude, then 18, contributed to the Kingsland Rovers' triumph in the 1921 third-grade championship. The following year, he remained on the third-grade team, who finished as runners-up in the 1922 championship, with Claude listed as "C List" and the other List as "J List."

In 1922, Claude continued playing for the Kingsland Rovers' third-grade team, now as runners-up in the championship and listed as "C List," with his brother Percy, possibly listed as "J List." By 1923, Claude advanced to the Kingsland's second-grade side. In 1924, he remained in the second grade, playing on the wing, and his team won the knockout competition. Early that season, he played against Devonport United as a curtain-raiser for the New Zealand v England test match. Claude was selected for the Auckland Junior representative side, playing Hamilton juniors twice in August and October, contributing to Auckland's victories with a try in the second match.

In 1925, Claude List achieved a notable season, marking his senior debut for Kingsland, which had joined the B Division of Auckland club rugby league. He stood out as one of the few players chosen for Auckland from that grade, a record he surpassed in 1928 by becoming the first New Zealand player selected for the national team from a lower division. His debut match took place on April 18 against Northcote & Birkenhead Rangers at Carlaw Park, where he scored three tries in a 21-3 victory. Claude's performance included an early try, a significant passing play resulting in a second-half try, and a third try after breaking away from a scrum.

In 1925, Claude List made a significant impact in his senior debut for Kingsland in the B Division of Auckland club rugby league, quickly becoming a standout player. His exceptional performance led to his selection for Auckland and eventually the national team, making him the first New Zealand player chosen from a lower division. Over the course of several games, List demonstrated his scoring abilities, including a match against Northcote & Birkenhead Rangers where he scored three tries, and another game with Māngere United where he added three more tries. Despite facing strong opposition and often being tackled just short of the line, List's impressive solo efforts and point-scoring abilities continued to shine through. His performances earned him recognition in the Auckland trial side, which was selected to play in a curtain-raiser match before the North Island v South Island game at Carlaw Park on June 27.

In the curtain-raiser match before the North Island vs South Island game at Carlaw Park on June 27, List, the Kingsland player, was chosen for the B team by selectors Edward Fox, Albert Asher, and Ronald McDonald. He contributed significantly to his team's 5-0 victory, making crucial saves and breaks. The New Zealand Herald praised his performance, highlighting his speed and skill as the best among the B team's backs. The Auckland Star mentioned that despite being a newcomer, List's performance was impressive, and he narrowly missed being selected for the New Zealand side to tour Australia.

After impressing in the curtain-raiser match, List, a newcomer to the senior game, narrowly missed being selected for New Zealand's tour to Australia. He served as a reserve for the Auckland side against New Zealand but did not play. The New Zealand Herald recognized his "particularly fine form," and he was considered for Auckland's Southern Tour. Following a loss by his club team, List was selected for the Auckland touring side to face West Coast, officially a B team with young players aged 19 to 22, as he was 22 and weighed 12 stone.

In the context of the previous text, after impressing in earlier matches and serving as a reserve, List was selected for Auckland's B team to play against West Coast. He scored a try in their victory, and after another appearance against Canterbury, he was chosen for the final tour match against Wellington. Auckland won the match heavily, and List contributed with another try, having also assisted a try for Ben Davidson.

In the final tour match, List scored a try that increased Auckland's lead to 23-4. His impressive performance led to his selection in the full Auckland side for their match against South Auckland. In his debut, List scored two tries, contributing to their 36-19 victory. He played on the wing, often attempting to break through the defense and assisting in tries for both himself and Ben Davidson.

After List's remarkable performance in the final tour match, scoring a try and helping Auckland secure a 23-4 lead, he was selected for the Auckland team in their match against South Auckland. Debuting with two tries, List's performance was praised by the Auckland Star, while the Herald noted his initial struggles. Despite his significant contribution to their 36-19 victory, List was chosen as a reserve for the Auckland Province match against Queensland, with Johnston and Delgrosso preferred on the wings. The Auckland Province suffered a heavy defeat, and List did not get the opportunity to replace the injured Raynor. Overall, List's impressive skills and potential were acknowledged, but his inexperience might have been a factor in the selection decisions.

In the match against South Queensland, Auckland Province suffered a large loss of 54-14, during which fullback Stan Raynor was injured and replaced by reserve forward Bill Te Whata, instead of List who was ready on the bench. This decision was criticized by the Herald, viewing it as an injustice to List and a questionable action by the selectors. In the 1926 season, List played 16 matches for Kingsland, scoring 11 tries and 1 goal, and made 4 appearances for Auckland, scoring 7 tries and participating in a New Zealand trial match. He also served on the Kingsland club committee. In the first game of the season, List scored all of Kingsland's points in a 6-5 loss against Otahuhu.

In the first game of the season, List, a winger, significantly contributed to Kingsland's performance by scoring all their points in a narrow loss against Otahuhu. He demonstrated his skills with a notable try in round 3's loss to Northcote and another in round 5's win over Parnell. His impressive form continued with a try in a victory against future champions Northcote. His outstanding efforts led to his selection as a reserve for a New Zealand trial match at Carlaw Park.

In the first game of the season, List, a Kingsland winger, significantly contributed to the team's performance, which led to his selection as a reserve for a New Zealand trial match. This trial match was a curtain-raiser for the North Island vs. South Island clash and part of a series of games to help select the New Zealand squad for a tour of England and Wales. List played in the B Team trial match and scored a try, receiving praise for his performance. Despite his impressive efforts, he was not selected for the New Zealand touring side. However, after two more strong performances for Kingsland, List was chosen for the Auckland side to play against the New Zealand team before they left.

In the match between Auckland and the New Zealand team, List, initially chosen as a winger, was moved to center when Leonard Riley couldn't play. Auckland won the festive-style game 52-32, with List scoring a try and contributing to Maurice Wetherill's try. Impressing the crowd of 14,000 at Carlaw Park, List's performance led the Herald to support his selection, while the Auckland Star criticized the exclusion of List, along with Ivan Littlewood and Hickey, from the New Zealand touring squad, particularly in the backline.

The text discusses the misfortune of several players, including List, who were not chosen for the New Zealand touring squad, with the Auckland Star expressing disappointment in this decision. The forwards on the team faced issues, with eight players refusing to play due to a conflict with the coach. This led to some backs, including List, playing in the forwards, and the offending players being banned for life. List later played well in a match against Otago, scoring a try and impressing the crowd. The Auckland Star continued to advocate for List's inclusion in the New Zealand squad, noting his high level of play and the talent of Auckland players in general.

After being overlooked for the New Zealand squad, List returned to his Kingsland team and scored six tries in two games. His impressive performance led to his selection in the Auckland squad to face Canterbury. In the match, List played in the centers, scored a try, and provided an assist. He also showcased his speed and strength in other instances, securing his team's victory. This further supports the Auckland Star's argument for List's inclusion in the New Zealand squad, highlighting his talent and form.

After being ignored for the New Zealand squad, List's remarkable performance in the Kingsland team, including six tries in two games, earned him a spot in the Auckland squad. His exceptional play against Canterbury, including a try and an assist, demonstrated his talent and form, supporting the Auckland Star's argument for his inclusion in the national team. Later, List's strong performance against Northcote, who won the match and the championship, showcased his abilities and the potential of other players in the B Division. As a result, List was selected for the Auckland side to face South Auckland, where Auckland won the match. Overall, List's impressive play and potential have been recognized, and he has been given more opportunities to showcase his skills.

In the match against South Auckland, Auckland emerged victorious with a score of 25-8, in front of a crowd of 3,000 at Carlaw Park. List significantly contributed to Auckland's win by scoring 3 tries. His first try was set up by Seagar's dummy, followed by List's cross-kick that enabled Wade to score. Later, List showcased his skills by catching a high reverse pass and diving across wide out for a try. Before the end of the first half, List created a successful raid, leading to Seagar's try. In the second half, List received the ball from Seagar and scored another try, securing Auckland's win.

In the second half of the match against South Auckland, List received the ball from Seagar and sprinted diagonally to score, significantly contributing to Auckland's victory. The Herald praised List's impressive straight running and skillful play. After the match, List returned to his Kingsland side and helped them win the Stallard Cup knockout final against Parnell. He set up a try for Carter and played excellently. In the 1927 season, List played 13 matches for Kingsland Rovers, scoring 2 tries, and 5 games for Auckland, leading in tries with 7. Despite the limited newspaper coverage of B Division matches, List's performance was remarkable, and he was selected for the 1927 North Island team.

In the 1927 season, List had a notable performance in both club and representative level rugby. He played 13 games for Kingsland Rovers, contributing to their season but finishing as runners-up to Ellerslie United. In Auckland's representative matches, List scored 7 tries in 5 games, leading in tries for the side. He also made his debut for the North Island team. The season started with List's selection for Auckland's match against returning members of the New Zealand team from their England and Wales tour. List's impressive straight running and skillful play were highlighted in the Auckland Star, as he scored a try and outperformed B. Davidson. This was Auckland's only representative match until late in the club season. List's performance in the B Division, despite limited coverage, earned him recognition and a spot on the North Island team.

In the 1927 season, List participated in 13 games for Kingsland Rovers from May to September, with significant performances in several matches. His skills and contributions, including a win against Otahuhu and a strong showing against Mangere, led to his recognition and selection for the North Island team. List's impressive play as a center three-quarter, such as in the B Division final against Ellerslie United, demonstrated his ability to seize opportunities and provide solid defense. Despite finishing as runners-up in the B Division, List's performance earned him praise in the Auckland Star.

In the 1927 season, List's exceptional performance as a center three-quarter for Kingsland Rovers, including a victory against Otahuhu and a notable game versus Mangere, secured his spot on the North Island team. His skills were further highlighted in the B Division final against Ellerslie United, with his performance earning him recognition in the Auckland Star. After a match against Parnell, List was selected for an Auckland tour, with the Star praising his abilities and comparing him to the renowned player Craddock Dufty. Ultimately, List was chosen as a back, along with other players, for the tour.

In the Auckland team's tour, some players withdrew, and the final selection included Charles Gregory, Craddock Dufty, Little, List, Joe Wilson jun., Maurice Wetherill, Stan Prentice, and Stan Webb. List, playing on the wing, scored a try in the first match against Canterbury at Christchurch, with the Christchurch Press praising his determination and ability to evade tacklers. Dufty's performance was also noteworthy, as he set up List's try in the second half. In the next match against the combined West Coast/Buller side, List scored another try, and the Grey River Argus highlighted the impressive performance of Prentice, Wetherill, and List.

During the Auckland team's tour, List, playing on the wing, made a notable impact with his tries and evasive skills, impressing local newspapers such as the Christchurch Press and the Grey River Argus. His performance was crucial in Auckland's victories against Canterbury and the combined West Coast/Buller side. After the tour, List was named in the reserves for the match against Otago but did not play in the final match against Wellington. He was then selected for his first North Island match against the South Island, playing on the wing alongside Stan Raynor, Maurice Wetherill, and Dufty. The North Island won the match, with List scoring a try in the first half. The Grey River Argus praised the performances of Prentice, Wetherill, and List, stating that they outplayed the opposition's key players. List's exceptional performance led to speculation that he would be chosen for a New Zealand side if one were picked that season.

The North Island emerged victorious in their match against the South Island with a final score of 13-8, thanks to List's try and Dufty's conversion. List's impressive performance, which included saving a try and making a hard-to-stop run towards the end of the game, led to speculation about his selection for a New Zealand side. In a later match, List contributed to Auckland's win against Buller with three tries, one of which he scored with a brilliant opening move.

In the North Island's victory against the South Island, List significantly contributed with a try and a conversion. His outstanding performance, which included a noteworthy opening move and powerful runs, sparked discussions about his potential selection for a New Zealand team. Throughout the season, List's exceptional abilities were further demonstrated by his three tries in Auckland's win against Buller, with one scored through a remarkable opening play. Despite his efforts, Auckland lost their final match to South Auckland (Waikato) 29-12, with List being the only Auckland back to impress the critics. Although he showed great skill, his tendency to hold onto the ball in scoring positions received some criticism. In 1928, List made his New Zealand debut after a successful season with Kingsland in the B Division, which, however, received minimal coverage.

In 1928, List started the season playing for Kingsland in the B Division, which received minimal coverage. He participated in all of Kingsland's matches, but it is unclear if he scored any tries. After their initial loss to Mangere United, observers noted that List was Kingsland's standout back and in good form for upcoming important matches. Following a victory over Northcote, List and another player, Carter, were praised for their impressive performance, significantly contributing to the win.

In the B Division season of 1928, List's outstanding performance as a back for Kingsland was highlighted, especially after their victory over Northcote, where he and Carter were instrumental in their win. Despite injuring his knee in the following game against Otahuhu, List continued to play and excelled on defense. His exceptional skills led to his consideration for the Auckland side, and he was later selected to play center in their match against South Auckland, where he scored two tries. The Auckland Star acknowledged List's talent, mentioning him as one of the top candidates for the center three-quarter position, along with Beattie.

In the 1928 B Division season, List's remarkable performance as a back for Kingsland gained attention, particularly after scoring two tries in their victory over South Auckland at Carlaw Park. His skills shone despite poor passes, and his strong running was noteworthy. After the game, List was recognized as a top candidate for the center three-quarter position in the Auckland side. He continued to excel in subsequent matches against Mangere and Grafton, leading to his selection in an Auckland Possibles side for an Auckland trial.

In the 1928 B Division season, List's exceptional performance as a back for Kingsland continued, most notably against Grafton on July 7, where he stood out as the best player on the field despite their loss. His skills led to his selection in an Auckland Possibles side for a trial match, aiming to determine the strongest team to face the England side touring soon. The Possibles side won the trial 24-14, with List scoring a try and being praised as the best wing player. He contributed to another try and later played for Kingsland against Point Chevalier on July 14, securing a 19-8 victory.

In the subsequent match on July 14, List's powerful running and effective fend helped Kingsland secure a 19-8 victory over Point Chevalier. His performance led to his selection for the Auckland team facing Canterbury on July 21 at Carlaw Park, where he played on the wing with Maurice Wetherill as the center. Auckland won the match convincingly, 66-26, with List scoring twice. Early in the game, he made a strong run on the right wing, passing to Prentice for a try. Later, he repeated the action, resulting in another try. He scored his first try in the second half through a passing run and a dash on the right wing, demonstrating his skill and versatility.

In the subsequent match, List's effective running and passing on the right wing led to two tries for himself and one assist, contributing to Auckland's significant victory. Despite his success, his performance on the wing was questioned, with suggestions that he might be better suited for the center position. However, his style of jumping over opponents was criticized as dangerous. In the following match against South Auckland, List scored a try but performed poorly as a center, even passing inappropriately to an unmarked teammate. As a result, he was only named as an emergency for the North Island side in the final match.

In the final match against South Auckland, List's misguided pass to a marked teammate while another was unmarked contributed to his limited selection as an emergency for the North Island side. However, his performance in the Possibles trial match earned him a spot on the wing for the team, which unfortunately lost the match. Despite this, List's skills were recognized, and he was selected for the New Zealand side to make his national debut in the first test against England, becoming the first player to be chosen for New Zealand while playing for a second division club. He was named in the center position alongside other notable players.

In the match against England, List, who was fortunate to be selected in the center position, contributed to New Zealand's surprising 17-13 victory. He scored a try after Wetherill kicked the ball to his direction, which he successfully caught and ran through to touch down. This win was significant as England had just come from a victorious tour in Australia. The New Zealand team employed a two five-eighths system, while the English used a different formation with two centers and a single five-eighth. The English centers, Jim Brough and Joe Oliver, were unable to stop List's try.

In the match against England, List, who was selected in the center position, played a crucial role in New Zealand's 17-13 victory by scoring a try. He ran through to touch down after catching a wide pass from Wetherill, which was kicked towards him while he was standing still. Despite England's recent victory in Australia and their different formation, their centers, Jim Brough and Joe Oliver, were unable to stop List's try. Following his impressive performance, List was chosen for the Auckland Provincial side to play England four days later, where he was in the centers opposite Mel Rosser. However, the Auckland Provincial side lost the match 14-9. Although the outcome was not favorable, List's performance was described as "sound" and "did well" in a subdued light.

In the match against England, the Auckland Provincial team, consisting of 12 Auckland club players, lost with a score of 14-9, even though List, one of the players, made a notable contribution by setting up their first try. Despite some handling errors possibly due to his teammates' performance, List was still selected for the Auckland side to face England again on August 11. This team was mostly composed of New Zealand representatives, but they still lost the match 26-15. Early in the game, List was involved in a play with Frank Delgrosso, demonstrating his active participation.

In the matches against England, List, a member of the Auckland Provincial team, made significant contributions such as setting up a try and intercepting a pass to prevent a score. He played opposite Jim Brough and Les Fairclough on the English side. Despite his active participation and notable plays, List was not selected for the second and third tests. He was initially considered for the second test, which New Zealand lost, and was bracketed for the third test but ultimately not chosen. The text suggests that List may have been injured, but it is not explicitly stated.

List's non-selection for the second and third tests against England might be attributed to an injured leg, as indicated by his unfit condition in a Kingsland match on September 8. Despite only playing half the game, he still showcased his skills, contributing to a try. By September 15, List had recovered enough to participate in Auckland's victory over Otago. His last game for Kingsland was a Stallard Cup semi-final loss on September 22, where he was involved in several tries.

List's injury prevented him from playing in the second and third tests against England, but he made a comeback in time for Auckland's victory over Otago on September 15. He showcased his skills in his final game for Kingsland, a Stallard Cup semi-final loss on September 22, where he contributed to several tries. Despite being criticized for relying too much on his fend, List was selected for the Auckland side and scored the opening try in their victory over North Auckland on October 6. The merger of Kingsland Rovers and Grafton Athletic at the start of the 1929 season formed the Kingsland Athletic club, which played in the first grade competition with maroon colors and a blue and gold shield.

After List's return from injury, he played in Kingsland's victory over Otago and contributed to tries in his final game for them. Despite criticism, he was selected for the Auckland side and scored in their victory over North Auckland. The merger of Kingsland Rovers and Grafton Athletic formed Kingsland Athletic, which competed in the first grade with maroon colors and a blue and gold shield. This marked List's first appearance in the first grade in his fifth season. He played 15 matches for Kingsland and 3 for Auckland, scoring a total of 9 tries and 1 drop goal. List's debut in the first grade with Kingsland ended in a loss against City Rovers, where he scored one of their two tries but was criticized for passing wildly. In the following match against Devonport, he had limited ball possession but delivered a strong defensive performance in another loss. The Auckland Star mistakenly attributed the original Grafton Athletic to the Maritime club, which had ceased in 1922.

After the merger of Kingsland Rovers and Grafton Athletic, List started playing in the first grade for Kingsland Athletic, appearing in 15 matches and scoring a total of 9 tries and 1 drop goal. His debut game resulted in a loss against City Rovers, where he scored one of their tries but was criticized for his passing. In the following matches, List's performance improved, and he delivered strong defensive displays in losses against Devonport and Newton. He was instrumental in setting up a try for R. Carter against Newton. Kingsland secured their first championship point with a draw against Marist Old Boys, where List was one of their best performing backs. Despite a heavy loss to Ponsonby, List's performance was praised, and he scored 2 tries in Kingsland's first win over Ellerslie. His performance was described as "outstanding," and his tries were highlighted for their brilliance.

Following the merger, List began playing first grade for Kingsland Athletic, making a notable impact with his performance. He scored a total of 11 tries in 17 matches, including a brilliant solo effort against City Rovers and a try in a loss to the same team. The Herald criticized his decision to hold onto the ball instead of passing, suggesting that Kingsland could have won more comfortably if he had passed more often. However, List's powerful running and try-scoring ability were praised, and he was instrumental in setting up tries for his teammates. His performance against Devonport and Newton was particularly impressive, where he set up tries and beat defenders with ease. Despite his strong performance, List faced competition for a place in the representative team as a center, but his powerful running and scoring ability made him a dangerous scoring back on the wing.

After the merger, List significantly contributed to Kingsland Athletic with his impressive try-scoring and powerful running as a center, although he faced competition for a spot on the representative team. His performance, particularly against Devonport, Newton, and Richmond, showcased his ability to set up tries and beat defenders. Despite criticism for holding onto the ball, List's outstanding play led to his selection for Auckland, where he excelled against South Auckland, overshadowing his opponent and setting up a try. However, his defensive play and passing accuracy were questioned. Overall, List's scoring ability and powerful running made him a valuable asset for Kingsland Athletic and Auckland.

Following the merger, List's exceptional try-scoring and strong running as a center greatly benefited Kingsland Athletic, even though there was competition for his position on the representative team. His performance, including his notable efforts against Devonport, Newton, and Richmond, showcased his skill at setting up tries and evading defenders. Although there were criticisms about his tendency to hold onto the ball and his passing accuracy, his scoring ability and powerful running made him a valuable player for both Kingsland Athletic and Auckland.

In a match against Ellerslie, List's performance was a highlight, as he caught a high kick and set up a try for Len Scott. However, the Herald criticized his passing, stating that he threw many wild passes to Scott and Mincham. Regardless, List's impressive play led to his selection for Auckland's training squad, where he scored a try in their 22–19 win over Northland. Although the Herald noted that he "kicked altogether too much" and suggested that he should have more confidence in his pace and strength, List was still chosen for the 22-man Auckland training squad to prepare for their match against Canterbury on August 24, and ultimately made the final side to play on the wing.

After being selected in Auckland's 22-man training squad and showing determination in their match against Canterbury, List made the final side to play on the wing, resulting in a 47-18 victory for Auckland. He scored the home side's last try, with the Herald praising his performance. In his final match of the season for Kingsland, they were defeated in the Roope Rooster knockout competition. List played 14 matches for Kingsland and scored 7 tries, placing him ninth in the club's try-scoring list. He only played one match for Auckland that season, despite being described as a "steady and resolute exponent with plenty of experience" in team previews.

He participated in one of Auckland's three matches, securing a victory of 21-16 against Northland. List played a significant role in Kingsland's attacking strategies. Following a loss to Devonport, he was selected for Auckland's training squad and faced Newton with Kingsland, resulting in a 14-8 loss. The Sun criticized his failure to run straight and provide enough space for his wingers. Despite this, he was chosen for Auckland's match against Northland, where they emerged victorious.

The match against Northland saw Auckland winning with a score of 21-16, attended by 8,000 spectators at Carlaw Park. List, the team member, had an uncharacteristically poor performance; he struggled with tackling, enabling Whitelaw to score a try. Critics, such as the Auckland Star and The Sun, pointed out List's uncertain movements, dropped passes, and inability to handle the change in position from center to wing. This subpar performance continued in Kingsland's subsequent match with Richmond. Given the New Zealand side's upcoming Australian tour in the same season, List's poor form could negatively impact his chances for further representative honors in 1930.

After a disappointing performance in the match against Northland, where List's poor tackling allowed Whitelaw to score, List continued to struggle in the following game against Richmond. His uncertain movements, dropped passes, and difficulty adjusting to the change in position from center to wing raised concerns about his impact on the New Zealand side's upcoming Australian tour and his chances for further representative honors in 1930. Due to his poor form, List was omitted from the Auckland side to play South Auckland. He spent the rest of the season playing for Kingsland, where he had a few good games, including scoring a try against Ellerslie and playing exceptionally well against City, becoming the team's best back and preventing a heavier defeat with his strong defensive skills. However, despite his improvement, he was unable to secure a spot on the Auckland side for the remaining matches against Ponsonby, Marist, and Devonport.

Following his omission from the Auckland side due to poor form, List played for Kingsland for the rest of the season. He showed improvement, becoming the team's best back and impressing with his defensive skills in several games. He scored tries against Devonport, Newton, and Ellerslie, and was instrumental in Kingsland's upset win over championship runners-up City Rovers. Despite his strong performances, he was unable to secure a spot on the Auckland side for the remaining matches. His season ended with a Roope Rooster round one loss, and he later joined Marist as part of the Kingsland merger in 1931.

After being left out of the Auckland team, List played for Kingsland for the rest of the season, significantly improving and becoming their top back. Despite his impressive defensive skills and contributions to Kingsland's wins, he couldn't return to the Auckland side. In 1931, Kingsland merged with Marist Old Boys due to Auckland Rugby League's decision to reduce the number of senior teams and create a reserve grade competition. As Marist now had access to Kingsland's top players, they emerged as early favorites for the competition. List joined Marist through this merger, with his final match being a Roope Rooster round one loss.

Following the merger of Kingsland and Marist Old Boys, List became a part of the strengthened Marist team, which now had access to Kingsland's top players, making them early favorites for the competition. List made an impact in his debut for Marist, scoring a try in the final minutes of the game against Richmond Rovers, resulting in a replay due to the game exceeding its scheduled time. His second match saw him score another try and kick a drop goal, but he missed their third match due to injury. List's performance in their round 7 win over Devonport demonstrated his continued impact, as he repeatedly broke through the opposing team's defense.

After missing a game due to injury, List returned to help Marist secure victories over Devonby, Richmond, Ponsonby, and City. His performance in these matches included scoring tries, making strong runs, and providing impressive passes to teammates. His skills have significantly improved since joining Marist, increasing his chances of earning representative honors this season.

Since joining Marist, List has significantly improved his handling skills, which has increased his chances of earning representative honors. Marist won their matches against Wellington combined clubs, Ellerslie-Otahuhu Leopards, and Devonport, with List scoring tries in the latter two games. His impressive performance against Devonport, where he outmaneuvered Seagar multiple times, led to his selection for the second time in the North Island team to play against the South Island. The Herald praised his current form and suggested that he could also be a valuable addition to the fullback position.

After his selection in the North Island team, List excelled in the match against the South Island, scoring three tries and outperforming his opponent, Jim Amos. The Herald praised his form and potential as a fullback, and he was noted as a key contributor to Marist's victories against various teams. His powerful and direct running style made him a dangerous back, as evidenced by his involvement in his teammates' tries and his own impressive scoring record. Despite a loss against Devonport in the Roope Rooster semi-finals, List's exceptional performance was recognized as he was considered the best back on the ground.

After standing out in the North Island match, List's impressive form continued in the Roope Rooster tournament. His powerful running and strong fending contributed to Marist's two tries in their close loss against Devonport. He was widely regarded as the best back in the game. However, List's season ended due to an injury, causing him to miss the Stormont Shield final and the combined Marist-Devonport sides match. The Herald reported a broken wrist, while The Star mentioned an injured hand. Despite his injury, List was selected for Auckland's match against Northland but couldn't participate. His 1932 season with Marist was noteworthy, as he led the team with 9 tries, the most by any player in Auckland.

The 1932 season was a pivotal one for List, as he excelled for Marist and New Zealand. He topped the Auckland try-scoring chart with 9 tries, contributing significantly to Marist's second-place finish in the Fox Memorial first grade championship. Regarding his personal life, List moved to New Zealand with his family, resided in Glen Eden, and later relocated to the inner city suburbs. After living on Paget Street in Freemans Bay in 1935, Claude List and his family moved to Hepburn Street in Ponsonby, where they resided throughout the 1940s. They subsequently relocated to Pollen Street in Ponsonby in 1949, staying until the mid-1950s, when they moved to Main Rd in Silverdale. Sadly, List passed away on April 17, 1959, at the age of 56.
